questions.question: A 27-year-old woman presents with a malodorous vaginal discharge that started a week earlier. On examination, the Whiff's test is positive, and the Gram stain shows the presence of clue cells. This infection is commonly treated with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Metronidazole Explanation: In this patient, bacterial vaginosis is confirmed by: Presence of clue cells on microscopy Positive Whiff test Clue cells are epithelial cells embedded with rod-shaped bacteria The antibiotic of choice is Metronidazole, a nitroimidazole antimicrobial Diagnosis Methods and Treatment for Bacterial Vaginosis Diagnostic Methods Amsel's Criteria Presence of clue cells (more than 20% of the total cell population) Positive whiff test Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge Microscopic Examination Detection of clue cells in vaginal smear Molecular Methods Detection of ribosomal RNA of Gardnerella vaginalis using PCR Treatment: First-Line Treatment Oral Metronidazole: 500 mg BD for 7 days Tinidazole 2 g orally for 3 days Alternative Treatment Clindamycin 300 mg orally BD for 7 days Nystatin pessary (Option B) : Nystatin pessary is used to treat vaginal candidiasis, characterized by thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge without malodor. The presence of clue cells and positive Whiff test rules out candidiasis. Tetracycline (Option C) : Tetracycline is not the first-line treatment for BV due to its broad spectrum and potential to further disrupt vaginal flora. It is more commonly used for conditions like chlamydia. Azithromycin (Option D) : This macrolide antibiotic is primarily used to treat cervicitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis and does not effectively target the anaerobic bacteria involved in BV. Reference: Williams Textbook of Gynecology, 4th Edition, Pages 56-57

questions.question: A 29-year-old female complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A Giemsa stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Curdy white discharge Explanation: Curdy white discharge is a hallmark of vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), which is caused by an overgrowth of Candida species. The discharge appears thick and white, often resembling cottage cheese. However, the condition described in this case is Trichomoniasis, which is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. Trichomoniasis typically results in a frothy, yellow-green discharge that may be foul-smelling, not a curdy white discharge. Trichomonas Vaginitis Trichomonas vaginitis, caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age, typically transmitted sexually. Symptoms: Yellowish-Green, Frothy Discharge: Foul-smelling. Vulvar Irritation & Itching : Around the vaginal opening. (Option D ruled out) Painful Urination (Dysuria): Burning sensation during micturition (Option C ruled out) Dyspareunia: Pain during intercourse. "Strawberry Cervix": Punctate hemorrhages on the cervix. (Option A ruled out) Recurrent Infections. Organism: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan. It thrives in the vaginal and cervical mucosa, causing inflammation. Infective & Diagnostic Stage: Trophozoite Diagnosis: Clinical Examination: Profuse, frothy yellow-green discharge. Strawberry cervix. Microscopy (Wet Mount): Motile Trichomonas vaginalis seen under

questions.question: A patient is seen in the OPD after her delivery, which was 5 days ago. She presents with smelly greenish vaginal discharge. What is the initial investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Per vagina examination Explanation: The first step in investigating smelly greenish vaginal discharge postpartum is a per vagina examination . This helps assess the discharge, identify signs of infection or inflammation, and collect samples for analysis, such as a vaginal swab, to determine the cause and guide management Trichomonas Vaginitis Trichomonas vaginitis, caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis, is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age, typically transmitted sexually. Symptoms: Yellowish-Green, Frothy Discharge: Foul-smelling. Vulvar Irritation & Itching: Around the vaginal opening. Painful Urination (Dysuria). Dyspareunia: Pain during intercourse. "Strawberry Cervix": Punctate hemorrhages on the cervix. Recurrent Infections. Organism: Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan. It thrives in the vaginal and cervical mucosa, causing inflammation. Infective & Diagnostic Stage: Trophozoite Diagnosis: Clinical Examination: Profuse, frothy yellow-green discharge. Strawberry cervix. Microscopy (Wet Mount): Motile Trichomonas vaginalis seen under the microscope. Vaginal pH: Elevated (>4.5). Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (NAAT): Gold standard for diagnosis. Culture: Less common, but highly accurate. Rapid Antigen Test: Point-of-care, less sensitive than NAAT. Treatment: Metronidazole or Tinidazole: Single or multi-dose regimen. Treat both sexual partners to prevent reinfection. Feature Bacterial Vaginosis Candidiasis Trichomoniasis Causative agent Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others Candida albicans or other Candida species Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan) Discharge appearance Thin, gray-white, homogeneous Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like" Yellow-green, frothy Odor Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH) None or mild Foul-smelling Vaginal pH > 4.5 ≤ 4.5 > 4.5 Whiff Test Positive (fishy odor with KOH) Negative May be positive Microscopy Clue cells, few lactobacilli Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores Motile trichomonads, many WBCs Associated symptoms Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia Itching, burning, erythema Treatment Metronidazole or clindamycin Fluconazole or topical antifungals Metronidazole or tinidazole Complete blood count (CBC) (Option A) CBC can help detect signs of infection, such as an elevated white blood cell count. However, it is not the first step in investigating postpartum vaginal discharge, though it may be ordered later if an infection is suspected or confirmed to evaluate the severity. USG (Option B) may be used if the per vagina examination suggests complications like retained placental tissue or uterine infection, but it is not the initial investigation for vaginal discharge. Urine analysis (Option C) is not relevant in this case, as the symptoms are focused on vaginal discharge. A urine test would be more appropriate if urinary tract infection (UTI) symptoms were present. Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th Edition, Page: 64-66.

questions.question: What are the potential long-term consequences of this condition in a 25-year-old female with a previous history of chlamydia infection who currently presents with mild fever, non-specific lower abdominal pain, mild diffuse tenderness upon deep palpation in the lower abdomen, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent discharge from the vagina?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Infertility Explanation: The patient likely has pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to a previous chlamydia infection, and untreated or recurrent PID can cause scarring and damage to the reproductive organs, particularly the fallopian tubes. This scarring can lead to infertility or an increased risk of ectopic pregnancy. PID is a major cause of infertility in women, especially if left untreated. Pelvic inflammatory disease Pathogenesis Infection ascends from the cervix and endometrium to the fallopian tubes and ovaries, causing inflammation and scarring. Can lead to infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain. Aetiology Acute: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, E. coli, Mycoplasma genitalium, Anaerobes (Bacteroides species), Gardnerella vaginalis, Trichomonas vaginalis, Streptococci, Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Actinomyces israelii. Chronic: Same as acute, with possible additional mixed infections. Clinical Features Signs: Fever, Purulent cervical discharge, Cervical motion tenderness, Adnexal tenderness, Abdominal tenderness. Symptoms: Lower abdominal pain, Abnormal vaginal discharge, Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse), Dysuria (pain during urination), Menstrual irregularities, Nausea and vomiting. Complications Infertility: Due to scarring and damage to fallopian tubes. Ectopic Pregnancy Chronic Pelvic Pain Peritonitis Sepsis Laboratory Findings Elevated WBC, Elevated CRP, Elevated ESR. Ultrasound: Thickened, fluid-filled fallopian tubes and free pelvic fluid. Next Step in Diagnosis Endocervical Swab: Detects key pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae to guide treatment and prevent complications. Treatment First-line Therapy: Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM single dose, or Cefoxitin 2g IM single dose + Probenecid 1g PO single dose, or Cefotaxime IV. Add Doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 14 days, with or without Metronidazole 500 mg PO BD for 14 days. Male Partner Treatment Treat with Cefixime + Azithromycin (Grey kit in India) to prevent reinfection. Out-patient Therapy (India) Yellow kit: Ceftriaxone, Doxycycline, Metronidazole for syndromic management. Uterine cancer (Option B): It arises from the lining of the uterus and is influenced by factors like hormonal imbalances and genetics. Chlamydia infection or PID is not a known cause of uterine cancer. Pelvic organ prolapse (Option C): Although chronic infections can contribute to pelvic floor weakness, pelvic organ prolapse is not a direct long-term consequence of chlamydia or PID. Cervical cancer (Option D): While chlamydia infection can increase the risk of acquiring other sexually transmitted infections (such as HPV), which is a known risk factor for cervical cancer, chlamydia itself is not a direct cause of cervical cancer. Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th Edition, Page: 69-72.

questions.question: Which of the following does NOT represent a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Thick white discharge Explanation: Thick white discharge is not a characteristic feature of bacterial vaginosis (BV). The discharge associated with BV is typically thin, grayish-white, and homogenous, rather than thick. Pathophysiology of BV: BV occurs due to a reduction in lactobacilli (normal vaginal flora) and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria such as Gardnerella vaginalis, Prevotella, Mobiluncus, and Bacteroides. Symptoms: Thin, foul-smelling vaginal discharge. Diagnosis: Based on Amsel criteria (at least 3 of 4 present) Amsel's Criteria for Bacterial Vaginosis (BV) Thin, gray-white discharge Homogeneous vaginal discharge, often malodorous. pH > 4.5 Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 is indicative. Positive Whiff Test Fishy odor when 10% KOH is added to the discharge. Clue cells on microscopy Vaginal epithelial cells coated with bacteria, giving a stippled appearance. Feature BV Normal Colposcopic findings (A, B) Homogeneous, milk-like secretions observed. Homogeneous, clear secretions seen. Microscopic findings (C, D) Gardnerella-like microbes and presence of clue cells on microscopy. Lactobacillus-like microbes observed with no clue cells. Microbial composition Overgrowth of anaerobes (e.g., Gardnerella vaginalis). Dominance of Lactobacillus species, maintaining vaginal acidity. Clinical significance Associated with fishy odor and elevated vaginal pH (>4.5), characteristic of BV. Represents a healthy vaginal microbiome with stable pH ( ≤ 4.5) and protective lactobacilli. Feature Bacterial Vaginosis Candidiasis Trichomoniasis Causative agent Overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis and others Candida albicans or other Candida species Trichomonas vaginalis (protozoan) Discharge appearance Thin, gray-white, homogeneous Thick, white, "cottage cheese-like" Yellow-green, frothy Odor Fishy (especially post-coital or with KOH) None or mild Foul-smelling Vaginal pH > 4.5 ≤ 4.5 > 4.5 Whiff Test Positive (fishy odor with KOH) Negative May be positive Microscopy Clue cells, few lactobacilli Hyphae or pseudohyphae, spores Motile trichomonads, many WBCs Associated symptoms Often asymptomatic, may have itching or irritation Intense itching, burning, dyspareunia Itching, burning, erythema Treatment Metronidazole or clindamycin Fluconazole or topical antifungals Metronidazole or tinidazole

questions.question: Identify the finding seen in this hysterosalpingogram:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bilateral hydrosalpinx Explanation: The given image is a hysterosalpingogram in which B/L fallopian tubes are blocked. Bilateral hydrosalpinx refers to the presence of fluid-filled dilatation or blockage of both fallopian tubes. This finding is characterized by the contrast agent filling the fallopian tubes and appearing as fluid-filled sacs on the HSG images . Bilateral hydrosalpinx can be a result of various conditions, such as infection, scarring, or previous pelvic surgery. Bilateral hydrosalpinx: Fallopian tube neoplasms are uncommon, with most fallopian tube masses being related to ectopic pregnancy or the aftermath of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). One of these conditions, hydrosalpinx, is a chronic cystic enlargement of the fallopian tube that results from distal tubal obstruction. On sonographic examination, hydrosalpinx appears as a thin-walled, cystic, fusiform structure with incomplete septa and anechoic content. In certain cases, multiple small hyperechoic nodules (2 to 3 mm) may form around the inner circumference of the tube, creating a " beads on a string " appearance. These nodules represent fibrotic endosalpingial folds. Hysterosalpingography, often performed for fertility evaluation, reveals ballooned, clubbed fallopian tubes filled with contrast. Management of hydrosalpinx depends on the certainty of the diagnosis, the woman's desire for future fertility, and the severity of symptoms. For asymptomatic women who have completed childbearing and whose sonographic findings support hydrosalpinx, expectant management is typically recommended. However, if pelvic pain or infertility is present, or if the diagnosis is uncertain, diagnostic laparoscopy is often performed. Extravasation into the venous system (Option B) would indicate that the contrast agent has leaked into the veins rather than following the normal flow through the fallopian tubes. This is an abnormal finding and typically not observed during a normal HSG. Normal HSG (Option C) refers to a hysterosalpingogram with no abnormal findings. In a normal HSG, the contrast agent should

questions.question: A patient came to the gynaecology OPD with complaints of foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge, and intense itching. On examination, the cervix and vagina were spotted and had the appearance of a strawberry. Identify the causative organism
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Trichomonas vaginalis Explanation: Trichomonas vaginalis is a protozoan parasite that causes trichomoniasis, a sexually transmitted infection. It is known to cause symptoms such as foul-smelling frothy vaginal discharge and intense itching. The cervix and vagina may appear reddened and have a characteristic appearance described as a "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" due to small red or punctate lesions on its surface. Incorrect Options: Gardnerella vaginalis (Option B) is a bacterium associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV), which is a common vaginal infection. BV typically presents with a creamy-white discharge with a fishy odor. However, it does not cause the characteristic "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" appearance seen in the given scenario. Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Option C) is the bacterium responsible for the sexually transmitted infection, gonorrhea. While it can cause vaginal discharge and itching, it does not typically produce the "strawberry cervix" appearance described in the question. Candida albicans (Option D) is a fungus responsible for vaginal yeast infections, also known as candidiasis. The typical symptoms include thick, white, curd-like discharge and itching. However, it does not cause the "strawberry cervix" or "strawberry vagina" appearance. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534826/ https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6758837/

questions.question: What is the diagnosis of an 18-year-old girl who has been experiencing low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and amenorrhea for the past six months? During examination, a pelvic mass is detected on the left side, and signs of ascites are present
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Tuberculosis with tubo–ovarian mass Explanation: The patient's presentation of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, amenorrhea, pelvic mass, and ascites is highly suggestive of genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis is a common extrapulmonary manifestation of tuberculosis, and it often involves the female genital tract, leading to tubo-ovarian masses, fallopian tube adhesions, and ascites. These clinical features are consistent with the diagnosis of tuberculosis with tubo-ovarian mass. Incorrect Options: While ovarian malignancy (Option B) can present with similar symptoms such as pelvic mass, weight loss, and abdominal pain, the presence of low-grade fever and signs of ascites makes tuberculosis a more likely diagnosis in this case. Ovarian malignancies typically do not cause systemic symptoms like fever, and ascites in ovarian cancer are usually associated with advanced disease. Ectopic pregnancy (Option C) refers to the implantation of a fertilized egg outside the uterine cavity, usually in the fallopian tube. While ectopic pregnancy can cause abdominal pain, amenorrhea, and pelvic mass, it is not typically associated with low-grade fever and ascites. Therefore, it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case. Submucous fibroids (Option D) are benign growths that develop in the uterine wall. They can cause symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure symptoms, but they are not typically associated with systemic symptoms like low-grade fever, weight loss, and ascites. Hence, submucous fibroid is an unlikely diagnosis in this case . Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5663156/#:~:text=Genital%20TB%20is%20a%20major,most %20sensitive%20test%20for%20diagnosis .

questions.question: What is the etiologic agent responsible for causing granuloma inguinale
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Calymmatobacterium Granulomatis Explanation: Granuloma inguinale, also known as donovanosis, is an infection caused by the gram-negative bacterium Klebsiella granulomatis or Calymmatobacterium granulomatis (Option A) . The incubation period can range from several days to weeks. The infection typically presents with painless inflammatory nodules that evolve into highly vascular, nontender ulcers. These ulcers eventually heal through fibrosis, which can lead to scar formation similar to keloids. Lymphadenopathy is generally absent. Diagnosis is primarily based on identifying Donovan bodies, which appear as "closed safety pins" when examined microscopically after Wright-Giemsa staining. Treatment of granuloma inguinale is azithromycin 1 g once a week for at least three weeks or until the lesions are fully healed. Other treatment options include doxycycline, ciprofloxacin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, or erythromycin base. Improvement is typically seen within the first few days of treatment, though complete resolution may take time, and relapses have been reported. Incorrect Options: Chlamydia trachomatis (Option B) is a bacterium that causes various sexually transmitted infections, including chlamydia. However, it is not the causative agent for granuloma inguinale. Chlamydial infections typically present with symptoms such as urethritis, cervicitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease. Ureaplasma urealyticum (Option C) is a bacterium that belongs to the family Mycoplasmataceae and can be associated with certain genital infections. However, it is not the causative agent for granuloma inguinale. Ureaplasma infections are more commonly linked to conditions such as urethritis, bacterial vaginosis, and infertility. Treponema pallidum (OptionD) is the bacterium responsible for syphilis, a sexually transmitted infection. While syphilis can cause genital ulcers similar to those seen in granuloma inguinale, the causative agent for granuloma inguinale is specifically Calymmatobacterium granulomatis, not Treponema pallidum. Reference: William's Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page 62

questions.question: What is the causative organism responsible for vulval warts among the following options?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Human Papilloma Virus Explanation: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is the causative organism of vulval warts. Vulval warts, also known as genital warts or condylomata acuminata, are sexually transmitted infection caused by certain types of HPV. HPV is a group of more than 100 related viruses, and the specific types responsible for genital warts are usually HPV types 6 and 11. Incorrect Options: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) (Option B) is not the causative organism of vulval warts. While HSV is another sexually transmitted infection, it is responsible for causing genital herpes, which presents with clinical features such as painful ulcers or blisters rather than warts. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) (Option C) is the virus that causes AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). HIV is not directly associated with the development of vulval warts. However, individuals with HIV infection or other conditions that compromise the immune system may have a higher risk of developing persistent or more extensive warts. Cytomegalovirus (Option D) is a common virus that can cause various manifestations, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems. However, it is not the causative organism of vulval warts. CMV is more commonly associated with infections such as congenital CMV infection, viral pneumonia, or hepatitis.

questions.question: A 28-year-old married woman who is anxious to conceive presents with copious vaginal discharge, without any itching. Her last menstrual period was 13 days ago. What is the cause of her vaginal discharge?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Physiological Explanation: The cause of her vaginal discharge is likely physiological , as increased discharge around ovulation occurs approximately 13 days after her last menstrual period. Leucorrhoea/Physiological vaginal discharge: Refers to an increase in normal vaginal discharge, which can vary in consistency and volume depending on the menstrual cycle. It can occur physiologically in the following conditions: Puberty Ovulation (where the discharge may become more copious and clear, resembling egg white consistency) Pregnancy Pre-menstrual phase (occasionally) The discharge may originate from the cervix or vagina, and a speculum examination can distinguish between the two. If the discharge is cervical, excessive mucoid secretion will be visible at the external os. Normal vaginal discharge is typically clear or white, odourless, non-itchy, and has a pH of 3.8-4.2. This type of discharge is not associated with pathology or infection. Candidiasis (Option A) is a fungal infection caused by Candida species, typically present with itching, thick white discharge resembling cottage cheese, and vulvar redness or swelling, which is not described here. Bacterial vaginosis (Option B) is caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria in the vagina, diagnosed using Amsel's criteria, which require at least three of the following five criteria: Clue cells (epithelial cells with adherent bacteria) present in >20% on microscopic examination. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5. Positive whiff test with potassium hydroxide (fishy odour). Thin, white, homogeneous vaginal discharge. Fishy odour. Trichomoniasis (Option C) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It typically presents with symptoms such as itching, a frothy yellow-green discharge, and a vaginal odour, none of which are described in this scenario. Reference: William’s Gynecology 4th Edition, Page 56,64,65

questions.question: A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Metronidazole Explanation: The clinical features, including frothy vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix, point towards trichomoniasis . The drug of choice is metronidazole. Trichomoniasis: Sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. Clinical Findings: Vulvar erythema and edema. Copious, frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge. Punctate lesions on the cervix (strawberry cervix). Vaginal pH > 4.5. Treatment: First-line Treatment: Metronidazole: 400 mg three times a day for 5 days or a single dose of 2 g. Alternative Treatments: Tinidazole: 2 g as a single dose. Secnidazole: 2 g as a single dose. Partner Treatment: Both partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent recurrence. Benefits of Single Dose Therapy: Ensures better compliance. Reference: Shaw’s Textbook of Gynecology, 17th Edition, Page 330

questions.question: A 24-year-old female presents with complaints of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. The wet smear of the discharge is shown below. The drug of choice to treat this condition is _____
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Metronidazole Explanation: A female with foul-smelling vaginal discharge and a wet smear showing clue cells is likely diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis . The drug of choice for bacterial vaginosis is metronidazole. Bacterial Vaginosis (BV): A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora. Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid. Pathogenesis: Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria. Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. Not sexually transmitted. Symptoms: 50% are asymptomatic. Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent. Minimal vulval irritation. Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features): White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall. Discharge with pH >4.5. Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test). Presence of clue cells on wet mount. Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria. Complications: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Chorioamnionitis Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) Preterm labor Treatment: Metronidazole (DOC) : 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%). Single 1 g dose cures only 45%. Clindamycin: 2% cream locally

questions.question: What is the likely diagnosis for the given image?
questions.explanation: . It can lead to tubal blockage, infertility, hydrosalpinx, pyosalpinx, tubo-ovarian masses, and pelvic adhesions. Diagnosis: Definitive: AFB on microscopy/culture or epithelioid granulomas on histopathology (low sensitivity). Imaging: Ultrasound, CT, MRI, and PET scan aid in diagnosis. Molecular Tests: PCR (high sensitivity, high false positives), Gene Xpert (promising for extrapulmonary TB). Laparoscopy (Gold Standard) : Reveals caseous nodules, tubercles, adhesions, shaggy areas, straw-colored fluid. Key Signs: Sharma’s Python Sign: Alternating constriction and dilatation of fallopian tubes. Sharma’s Kissing Fallopian Tubes Sign: Fusion and blockage due to caseous material and adhesions. Image showing kissing fallopian tube sign. Nodules are also seen Normal Fallopian Tube (Option B) : The fallopian tube normally appears thin-walled, mobile, and patent with a uniform lumen. No tubal distortion, adhesions, or nodules are seen in normal tubes. Hydrosalpinx (Option C) : It refers to fluid-filled, dilated fallopian tubes due to chronic infection or tubal blockage . The tube appears distended, with a thin wall and no internal nodules. In contrast, genital TB causes thickened walls with caseous nodules and adhesions, as seen in the given image. Endometriosis (Option D) : It leads to chocolate cysts (ovarian endometrioma), dense adhesions, and powder-burn lesions on the peritoneum, uterus, and ovaries. Unlike TB, it does not show caseous nodules or tubal beading. Image showing kissing ovaries sign (sonographic sign of moderate to severe endometriosis)

questions.question: Kassowitz rule is related to:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Congenital syphilis Explanation: Kassowitz rule pertains to congenital syphilis and describes the impact of untreated syphilis in successive pregnancies. Kassowitz Rule: The rule states that if a woman with untreated syphilis has multiple pregnancies, the risk of fetal infection decreases with each subsequent pregnancy. In the first pregnancy, the outcome is usually an abortion. In subsequent pregnancies, the outcomes may involve stillbirths, and eventually, later pregnancies can result in live births with congenital syphilis. Congenital Syphilis: Congenital syphilis occurs when Treponema pallidum is transmitted from an infected mother to the fetus, leading to complications like fetal death, preterm labor, and stillbirth if untreated. Transmission Routes Transplacental (through the placenta) Perinatal (during delivery) Clinical Features Jaundice Ascites Petechiae and Purpura Pneumonia Myocarditis Long Bone Involvement Treatment: Penicillin Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th Edition, Page: 1207

questions.question: Which of the following drugs cannot be given in bacterial vaginosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Erythromycin Explanation: Erythromycin is not commonly used to treat bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial Vaginosis (BV): A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora. Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid. Pathogenesis: Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria. Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. Not sexually transmitted. Symptoms: 50% are asymptomatic. Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent. Minimal vulval irritation. Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features): White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall. Discharge with pH >4.5. Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test). Presence of clue cells on wet mount. Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria. Complications: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Chorioamnionitis Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) Preterm labor Treatment: Metronidazole (DOC): (Option C) 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%). Single 1 g dose cures only 45%. Clindamycin: (Option A) 2% cream locally (85% effective). Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days. Alternatives: Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, tinidazole or sulfa drugs. (Option D) Reference: Shaws textbook of Gynaecology 17th Edition, Page 330,331

questions.question: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of profuse vaginal discharge. The discharge has a fishy odour. Microscopy revealed the cell shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Bacterial vaginosis Explanation: A female with profuse vaginal discharge and a fishy odor, along with clue cells on microscopy, is most likely to have Bacterial vaginosis. Bacterial Vaginosis (BV): A polymicrobial condition characterized by an alteration in normal vaginal flora. Minimal inflammatory response; few leukocytes in vaginal fluid. Pathogenesis: Decreased lactobacilli, leading to increased pH and overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria. Common bacteria: Gardnerella vaginalis, Mobiluncus spp., Mycoplasma hominis, and Haemophilus vaginalis. Not sexually transmitted. Symptoms: 50% are asymptomatic. Vaginal discharge: white, milky, non-viscous, and adherent. Minimal vulval irritation. Amsel's Criteria (Diagnostic Features): White, milky, nonviscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall. Discharge with pH >4.5. Fishy odor on adding 10% KOH (whiff test). Presence of clue cells on wet mount. Reduced lactobacilli and increased pathogenic bacteria. Complications: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Chorioamnionitis Premature rupture of membranes (PROM) Preterm labor Treatment: Metronidazole (DOC): 400 mg twice daily for 7 days (effective in 85%). Single 1 g dose cures only 45%. Clindamycin: 2% cream locally (85% effective). Oral 300 mg daily for 7 days. Alternatives: Ampicillin, cephalosporin, tetracycline, doxycycline, tinidazole or sulfa drugs. Herpes (Option A) typically presents with painful blisters or ulcers on the genital area, not with profuse vaginal discharge or clue cells. Candida albicans (Option B) causes thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge, itching, and presents with pseudohyphae and yeast cells on KOH mount, but not a fishy odor or clue cells on wet mount. Trichomonas vaginalis (Option C) causes frothy, greenish-yellow discharge with itching, burning, and motile trichomonas on

questions.question: Identify the condition shown below?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Condyloma accuminata Explanation: The image shown indicates Condylomata acuminata. Condylomata Acuminata (Anogenital Warts): Caused by Human Papillomavirus (HPV), primarily strains 6 and 11. Mainly transmitted through sexual contact. Risk Factors: Age, lifestyle, and sexual practices influence susceptibility. Diagnosed clinically, but histopathological examination reveals acanthosis, hyperkeratosis, and koilocytes (large keratinocytes with pyknotic nuclei). Clinical Features: Usually asymptomatic, though they may cause bleeding, pruritus, and pain. Typically appear as raised, skin-colored, fleshy papules. Size ranges from one to five millimeters in diameter. Can be broad and flat, pedunculated (on a stalk) , or occasionally have a cauliflower-like appearance. Lesions are commonly found in multiples and may coalesce. Present in the anogenital region or, less frequently, the oral cavity. Management: Treatment is typically not required for lesions that resolve spontaneously. Persistent or symptomatic lesions: Topical therapies (e.g., podophyllotoxin, imiquimod), cryotherapy, TCA application, or surgical excision. Surgical methods like electrosurgery and laser therapy are effective for refractory cases. Condyloma lata (Option A) is associated with secondary syphilis and typically presents as flat, broad, wart-like lesions. These lesions are painless and have a moist appearance, often occurring in the genital area. Molluscum contagiosum (Option B) is caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus and results in small, dome-shaped papules or nodules with a central depression. These lesions are typically painless and can be found on various areas of the body. None of the Above (Option D): This option is not correct in this context because the image does indeed resemble a specific skin condition, and that condition is Condyloma acuminata, not ‘None of the Above’.

questions.question: A woman comes with complaints of pain and swelling in the perianal area. She also has complaints of difficulty in walking and sitting. She gives a history of multiple sexual partners. On examination, tender swelling is seen with redness on the labia, as shown in the image given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Bartholin abscess The clinical features here of pain, swelling, redness, and a tender mass on the labia are characteristic of a Bartholin abscess. The Bartholin gland becomes blocked, leading to the accumulation of fluid and subsequent infection. Bartholin cyst characteristics: Painless, smooth, cystic swelling in inferior labia majora or posterior vestibule near the fourchette. Bartholin gland characteristics: Bilateral, 0.5 to 1 cm in diameter, located deep to vestibular bulb and bulbospongiosus muscle. Complication: Infection can lead to abscess formation. Common Pathogens: E. coli, gram-positive/negative aerobes, anaerobes. Clinical Features: Severe vulvar pain during walking, sitting, or coitus Swelling Erythematous and red swelling

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman with a history of multiple sexual partners presents with lower abdominal pain for 1 month. She experiences minimal discharge and complaints of inter-menstrual bleeding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Neisseria gonorrhoea The clinical scenario points to an infection due to Neisseria gonorrhoea leading to pelvic inflammatory disease. Morphology: They are cocci that have pili that help in adhesion to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. They penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach the subepithelial tissue by the 3 rd day of infection. Clinical features: Urethritis Cervical discharge: Purulent and thick Pruritis Dysuria Intermenstrual bleeding Specific features of the disease: About half of the female patients remain asymptomatic The ectocervix and vagina remain unaffected , usually The main sites of infection are the columnar and transitional epithelium It initially affects the cervix and urethra and may extend to the Bartolin’s glands, skene glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes (salpingitis) Complications: Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis can lead to sterility Tubo-ovarian abscesses Ectopic pregnancies Peritonitis with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome) In Males: Acute urethritis can extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis Mucopurulent genital discharge resembling the ‘flow of seed’ (semen) Urethral strictures Water-can perineum due to the spread of infection to the periurethral tissues, leading to abscesses and multiple discharging sinuses Genital tuberculosis (Option B) presents with irregularities in the menstrual cycle but may also be associated with systemic symptoms such as fever, malaise, and weight loss. It may also be associated with concurrent pulmonary disease. Vaginal candidiasis (Option C) presents with intense pruritus and copious vaginal discharge that has a cottage cheese appearance. Herpes simplex (Option D) appears as blisters that develop into painful ulcers on breaking.

questions.question: A 29-year-old woman presents with painless ulcers on the vulva; she gives a history of having multiple sexual partners. From the given options, what is the next best step to arrive at a diagnosis based on these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) VDRL Explanation: History of multiple sexual partners suggests a possibility of sexually transmitted disease, and the most common cause of painless genital ulcer is syphilis. The test for syphilis is the Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test. Syphilis is caused by a spirochete called Treponema pallidum. Painless genital ulcers can be caused by several STIs, including syphilis (M/c), donovanosis, and lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). Investigations for syphilis: Serological tests: Nontreponemal and treponemal-specific tests Non-treponemal tests Treponemal-specific tests VDRL test RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin test) FTA-ABS TP-PA Both these tests measure IgM and IgG antibodies against cardiolipin. False positives: Recent vaccination Febrile illness Pregnancy IV drug abusers SLE Ageing Cancer They remain positive for life after the infection. While NAT (Option B) can be used to detect various STIs, such as HIV, hepatitis B, and hepatitis C, it is not typically the first-line diagnostic test for syphilis. VDRL is more commonly used for screening and initial diagnosis of syphilis. Vaginal swab and culture (Option C) can be used for fungal and bacterial infections with vaginal discharge. This option may be appropriate for diagnosing other genital infections, such as bacterial vaginosis or candidiasis, but it is not the most suitable test for diagnosing syphilis. The polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (Option D) is a technique for amplifying many copies of a specific DNA sequence. It is used in many bacterial and viral infections, including syphilis. However, it is not the first line of investigation. Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page: 60, 61, 62.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions has the lowest occurrence of perinatal transmission?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Rubella Explanation: Rubella/ German measles is transmitted via nasopharyngeal secretions; hence, perinatal transmission is not seen in this case. Characteristics It is an RNA togavirus Transmission Nasopharyngeal secretions Maternal features Mild febrile illness Generalized maculopapular lesion beginning on the face and then spreading to the trunk and extremities Arthralgia or arthritis Head and neck lymphadenopathy Conjunctivitis Spontaneous abortions Devastating fetal infections Fetal features 13 to 14 gestation: 50% incidence of an affected fetus End of 2nd trimester: 25% After 20 weeks: Defects are rare Diagnosis Urine analysis Blood analysis Nasopharyngeal secretions CSF analysis ELISA: Specific IgM antibody Management and prevention Droplet precautions for 7 days after onset of rash Postexposure passive immunization with IVIG within 5 days of exposure MMR vaccine to non-pregnant women of childbearing age Targeted USG to determine fetal anomalies in infected mothers Vaccination of all susceptible hospital personnel Hepatitis B (Option A) transmission transplacentally is uncommon but vertical transmission is seen by exposure to blood or other bodily fluids during birth. All pregnant mothers are screened at the beginning of the pregnancy, and if found positive, the newborns are given hepatitis B immunoglobulin with a hepatitis B recombinant vaccine series. In HSV (Option B) , Fetal infection can occur by shedding of virus from the lower genital tract during vaginal delivery or rupture of membranes. Neonatal infection, when symptomatic, can present with chorioretinitis, mental retardation, microcephaly, seizures, and occasionally death. CMV (Option D) is a DNA virus transmitted by sexual, respiratory droplets and transplacental route . Infection can affect the fetus throughout gestation and cause microcephaly, intracranial calcification, chorioretinitis, mental retardation, nonimmune hydrops, stillbirth, IUGR, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and sensorineural deafness. Transmission is more common in the third trimester and during delivery. Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page: 1036, 1037, 1183, 1190, 1191.

questions.question: What are clue cells?

options.A: Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria
options.B: Cervical epithelial cells lined by bacteria
options.C: Uterine endothelial cells lined by bacteria

questions.explanation: Correct Answer A - Vaginal epithelial cells lined by bacteria Clue cells are epithelial cells in the vagina that have bacterial growth on them, giving them a unique stippled look. These are found in bacterial vaginosis and are one of the criteria for its diagnosis. They are cells with attached bacteria creating a poorly defined, stippled cellular border. The Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis require the presence of at least three out of the following five criteria: 1. Presence of clue cells (>20%) on microscopic examination Clue cells: Epithelial cells lined with bacilli 2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5 3. Positive whiff test with KOH (fishy odor) 4. Thin, white homogeneous vaginal discharge 5. Fishy odour Reference: Williams Gynecology, 4th edition, Page: 57.

questions.question: A 28-year-old female presents to the clinic complaining of severe vaginal irritation and pruritus. On examination, you note a greenish-yellow, frothy discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Trichomoniasis Explanation: The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Trichomoniasis. This condition is caused by Trichomonas vaginalis, a protozoan parasite. It is the most common cause of vaginitis in women of reproductive age. It is characterized by the following symptoms: Sudden, profuse, yellowish-green, frothy, foul-smelling discharge Vaginal irritation and pruritus Painful urination Pain during intercourse Recurrent infections Inflamed vulva Inflamed vaginal walls with small, punctate hemorrhages, also known as 'strawberry cervix' Treatment of Trichomoniasis: Metronidazole 500 mg thrice daily for 1 week or a single 2 g dose. Tinidazole 2 g single dose (equally effective). Both partners should receive the same regimen to prevent reinfection. Male partner should use a condom during intercourse until the female partner completes treatment. Differential Diagnosis: Bacterial vaginosis (Option A): Typically presents with malodorous, thin, grayish-white discharge Associated with overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria like Gardnerella vaginalis Candidiasis (Option C): Presents with thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge Associated with itching and irritation Gonorrhea (Option D): Usually presents with purulent and yellowish-green discharge Not typically frothy May not present with severe irritation and pruritus Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th Edition, Page 64-66

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist complaining of curd-like white vaginal discharge. Upon examination, the physician observes that when attempting to remove the discharge, petechiae are seen. What condition is most likely causing these findings?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Candidiasis Explanation: Candidiasis: A fungal infection caused by Candida albicans Characteristic presentation includes: Curd-like white discharge Plaque on the vaginal wall that causes petechiae when removed Out of proportion pruritus and splash dysuria are common symptoms Differential Diagnosis: Trichomoniasis (Option B): Presents with greenish-yellow, frothy discharge Pruritus present Does not cause petechiae on removal of discharge Gardnella vaginalis (Option C): Presents with thin creamy white discharge with fishy odour No associated petechiae on examination Gonorrhea (Option D): Presents with purulent yellow-green vaginal discharge No characteristic petechiae formation Reference: Vulvovaginal Candidiasis - STI Treatment Guidelines Berek and Novak's Gynecology, 16th Ed, Ch.15, Table 15.2

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman from an endemic area presents with chronic pelvic pain, irregular menstrual cycles, and primary infertility. She has a history of pulmonary tuberculosis treated 5 years ago. Her gynecologist suspects genital tuberculosis and is discussing the pattern of organ involvement with medical students. Most common organ infected with genital tuberculosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B. Fallopian tube Explanation: The Fallopian tube is the correct answer because: It is always the first structure to be involved in genital tuberculosis The distribution of involvement of Fallopian tubes in cases of genital tuberculosis is 90%-100% Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th Edition Page 437-438
